title: Is the coronavirus predicted in any book? - Quora

response.answer_text: The novel coronavirus pandemic has gripped the world with a deadly disease spreading like wildfire, affecting thousands of people. In India, the number of positive cases has crossed the 100 mark and the death toll has touched three people. In a scenario where panic is as contagious as the virus, rumours take no time to become viral. Some stories of uncanny predictions are also doing the rounds. Here's a list: A book from 1981 The Eyes of Darkness, a novel written by Dean Koontz and published in 1981, allegedly predicted the outbreak of a coronavirus. There is a passage in the book that alludes to the creation of a deadly virus known as Wuhan-400, which is named after the place where it originated. Netizens are going gaga over the strange similarity and many are saying that the author was one person who foresaw the occurrence of COVID-19. A prediction in The Simpsons More often than not, The Simpsons is credited with predicting that Donald Trump would become the President of United States. "The Simpsons predicted it” is a common phrase on the internet. A 1993 episode of the animated sitcom titled Marge in Chains dealt with the outbreak of a mysterious virus that originated in the Far East. The episode focuses on an illness called 'Osaka flu' that spreads through Springfield after residents order juicers from Japan. Nostradamus predicted this? Nostradamus, the 16th-century French astrologer, physician and reputed seer is famous for his predictions. From the end of the world to natural calamities, his predictions are dynamic and mind-boggling. And according to one Twitter user, Nostradamus also predicted the coronavirus. The authenticity of the user's claim is debatable.  'The war of Armageddon' Jeane Dixon was an American psychic who reportedly predicted the 1963 assassination of John F. Kennedy. Dixon also predicted that the world would end in 2020 when a 'war of Armageddon' would wipe out the planet. According to netizens, the Armageddon that she was referring to was the coronavirus. End of Days Pictures of a page from a book titled End of Days, written by late Sylvia Brown, has gone viral on social media. Certain lines in the book make it seem like the author had predicted that a coronavirus-like epidemic would attack the world in 2020. Here's an excerpt: "In around 2020 a severe pneumonia-like illness will spread throughout the globe, attacking the lungs and the bronchial tubes and resisting all known treatments. Almost more baffling than the illness itself will be the fact that it will suddenly vanish as quickly as it arrived, attack again ten years later, and then disappear completely." All of these predictions may just be shots in the dark. For now, people need to keep themselves safe by following the guidelines shared by governments, medical experts and the World Health Organization. Reference:- Coronavirus: Did you know about these predictions?

“No one could have seen this coming” they say. But any Native American can tell you otherwise. ———————————— [I’m not an expert. I’m synthesizing information so that I can make the best decisions for my business in the next 12–36 months. Take what I say with a grain of salt. If you have better information please add it with a comment and link to the source.] ———————————— Two years ago I posted on Facebook that viruses were the largest threat to Native Americans. A little bit of xenophobia would have been good for them. My friends were none too kind with their responses:  Pathogens have decimated populations probably since the dawn of time. And they will continue to do so. Lindy Effect The Lindy Effect says that something will be relevant in the future for about as long as it was relevant in the past. The bible has been relevant for 2,000 years. Shakespeare has been relevant for 500 years. Twitter has been relevant for 15 years. You get the idea. Epidemics have been relevant since… forever. How this compares to Coronavirus What’s notable in this example (Source: Acuna-Soto, et al 2002) from Mexico is that 21 out of 22 million native people in Mexico died from pathogens, around 95% of the population. Compare this to the Diamond Princess where 0.2% of people died. The Native Americans had no immunity to the new viruses, Smallpox “imported” from Europe and Cocoliztli possibly native. But the people on the Diamond Princess seem to have had some immunity — only 19% were infected despite the close quarters. Perhaps there is some natural immunity among humans to COVID-19. This gives me hope in our current situation that we won’t end up like the unlucky natives 500 years ago. However, decimated populations are Lindy. If it’s been relevant since the dawn of time, it could happen again. In fact it will. Let’s look at what happened back then to see what we can do now to protect ourselves. Why were Native Americans so susceptible? The new world wasn’t colonized by guns; it was colonized by chickens. That probably sounds strange. We were taught that the brutal colonizers killed a lot of people. And they did. But guns didn’t cause the majority of deaths. You see, in the New World people had very few domesticated animals — only dogs and llamas. You’ve heard of avian flu and you’ve heard of swine flu but you probably never heard of llama flu or dog flu. Because those animals generally don’t pass on viruses to humans. They’re just not similar enough. Europeans living in close proximity to domesticated animals like pigs and chickens built up immunity over time. Then they brought these viruses to the new world which wiped out the native people. The native people didn’t have domesticated chickens to help them build up immunity. This helps explain how we make vaccines. The most common way is with chicken eggs. We inject a virus into a fertilized chicken egg, the virus multiplies and then we extract the virus. We then purify the antigen, a molecule from the virus that our antibodies need to be exposed to. We then inject that antigen into humans who can now get the exposure to the antigen without being exposed to the virus.  Source. A Tangent on Wheels. The reason Native Americans never invented the wheel, supposedly, was because they didn’t have domesticated animals. They didn’t have beasts of burden like oxen or horses. Thus, there was not much use in having a wheel because there was no animal to pull a wheeled cart. But wheelbarrows don’t require beasts of burden. Thus, it’s still a mystery why they never invented wheels. At the very least you can see the utility of the wheel was substantially less for people who didn’t have horses or oxen. Back to the original story… How can we see it coming next time? This is the hard and the simple question to answer. Simply, anything that happens rarely but repeatedly will happen again and surprise us: Economic crashesWorld warsParadigm shifts in science (Heliocentrism, Newton’s laws of motion, Relativity, etc.)Change of super powers, no super power has lasted more than 1,000 yearsMeteorites hitting the earthNew ReligionsAlien invasions (ok, just kidding about this one)The hard answer is I don’t know how to predict these things. Do you know? Let me know in the comments. I’m very curious.

Such an outbreak was predicted as likely in a research paper, Bat Coronaviruses in China, published in March 2019, written by scientists working in Wuhan, the centre of the outbreak in China. Details: Bat Coronaviruses in China, Published online 2019 Mar 2. Authors: Yi Fan, Kai Zhao, Zheng-Li Shi, and Peng Zhou, from the CAS Key Laboratory of Special Pathogens and Biosafety, Wuhan Institute of Virology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Wuhan 430071, China. Introduction: “Fifteen years after the first highly pathogenic human coronavirus caused the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) outbreak, another severe acute diarrhea syndrome coronavirus (SADS-CoV) devastated livestock production by causing fatal diseases in pigs. Both outbreaks began in China and were caused by coronaviruses of bat origin [1,2]. This increased the urgency to study bat coronaviruses in China to understand their potential of causing another virus outbreak. In this review, we collected information from past epidemiology studies on bat coronaviruses in China, including the virus species identified, their host species, and their geographical distributions. We also discuss the future prospects of bat coronaviruses cross-species transmission and spread in China.” The prediction comes in this section in the paper. 2.3. Why China? Two bat CoVs caused outbreaks in China; it is thus urgent to study the reasons to avoid future outbreaks. China is the third largest territory and is also the most populous nation in the world. A vast homeland plus diverse climates bring about great biodiversity including that of bats and bat-borneviruses—most of the ICTV coronavirus species (22/38) were named by Chinese scientists studying local bats or other mammals. The majority of the CoVs can be found in China (Table 1). Moreover, most of the bat hosts of these CoVs live near humans, potentially transmitting viruses to humans andlivestock. Chinese food culture maintains that live slaughtered animals are more nutritious, and this belief may enhance viral transmission. It is generally believed that bat-borne CoVs will re-emerge to cause the next disease outbreak. In this regard, China is a likely hotspot. The challenge is to predict when and where, so that we can try our best to prevent such outbreaks.

These leaps of viruses from animals to humans are mostly due to mutations in the virus, many viruses being specific for which species they infect.In seldom cases the leap can be due to new contact with animals we usually do not have contact with. All these leaps of viruses from animals to humans have some things in common. The most important is ALL the antigens on the virus being new to humans, meaning No humans have ANY innate resistance at all against the virus. Let us compare this with the seasonal flu. With the seasonal flu, the main antigens mutate. This makes us vulnerable to the mutated virus even if we had the flu in the former years, and is why we have new flu shots every year. But still the “new” flu viruses are not totally new after all, as they still carry on them several of their old antigens. These antigens they continue to have, do we have some resistance against. This is why the Spanish Flu, the Avian flu and the Swine flu was different from the ordinary flus. All these flus came new from animals, and no human had any resistance against any of the antigens on them. The covid-19 virus is the same (even if it is not a flu), it came “new” from some animal, possibly bats on the “wetmarked” in Wuhan. No human have any prior immunity against any of the antigens on the virus. That makes us vulnerable to it. Being viruses, they spread like viruses. Viruses can differ in how contagious they are, the most contagious virus we know being the measles virus.But most viruses spread in such a way that every infected person, infects more than one other person. This is what we call “viral spread”. What makes a virus more or less infectious are:How much the infected person excrete the virusHow long time does an infected person excrete virusesHow long does an infected person survive? If a virus kills the infected person too quickly, it has not enough time to infect others.How high virus load (how many viruses) it takes to make a person infectedHow long does the virus survive outside the body, and on which surfaces does it surviveWhat are the infection routes: Contact infection, airborne infection, infection by water, infection by food, infection by vectors like mosquitoes Epidemiologists study these questions, and study how to deal with them.

There are reports of numerous intelligence reports predicting such a pandemic virus, including a January 2017 briefing by outgoing Obama officials to incoming Trump administration officials, but this was about a pandemic in general, not the COVID-19 virus specifically. There was one report published in China in Jan 2019 (rev Feb 2019) that has so much specificity that it could be considered the first scientific prediction of COVID-19. It is referred to as Bat Coronaviruses in China. Viruses 2019, 11, 210, by Fan, Y.; Zhao, K.; Shi, Z.-L.; Zhou, P. If anyone has an earlier scientific paper that predicted COVID-19, I’d be most interested in hearing about it. But please, NO conspiracy theories. Thx.
